Body:
BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Wednesday, 06/09/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT30) PHOENIX -- June 9, 1999 -- DRUG-TREATMENT-2, 6-9 --
Albert Delatorre listens to another patient recovering from drug
addiction, before during a group therapy session. In defiance of
Arizona's political establishment, voters took the law into their
own hands and voted twice, by large majorities, to make their state
the first to mandate treatment instead of prison for criminal
offenders whose primary legal problem is drug use. (Monica
Almeida/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT29) NARITA, Japan -- June 9, 1999 -- TOKYO-AIRPORT-FARMERS,
6-9 -- Shoji Shimamura farms his land near Narita International
Airport, visible on the horizon. The airport has struggled for
years to expand beyond one runway. However the ability of Shimamura
and fellow farmers to hold up a vast project like Narita's
expansion, at incalculable economic costs for Japan, underscores
the difficulties that the Japanese political process has in
creating losers. (Nicholas D. Kristof/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT28) KAFANCHAN, Nigeria -- June 9, 1999 --
NIGERIA-ETHNICGROUPS, 6-9 -- Bashir Idris in front of his home
burned by rioters. Clashes in this northern Nigerian town, like the
ethnic violence that has erupted elsewhere across Nigeria in recent
months, are rooted in a struggle over political dominance. The
trouble began here when the local emir died in November after
ruling this town in northern Nigeria for 40 years. (Norimitsu
Onishi/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT27) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- GUN-JUVENILES, 6-9 --
House Minority Leader Richard Gephardt, third from left, flanked by
fellow House Democrats, talks to reporters before a strategy
meeting on gun control legislation on Wednesday. President Clinton
on Wednesday denounced House Republicans' gun-control proposals as
measures that were ``plainly ghostwritten'' by the National Rifle
Association, which he and House Democratic leaders said had
succeeded in weakening the gun-control language in legislation
passed by the Senate last month. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)
(NYT26) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- DEFENSE-SPENDING, 6-9 -- Rep.
Christopher Cox, (R-Calif.) left, talks to reporters as Rep. Norm
Dicks, D-Wash., looks on during a news conference on Capitol Hill,
Wednesday. The House debated a Republican-drafted measure Wednesday
that would cut off future funds for military operations in the
Balkans. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT25) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- CLINTON-POLICE-RACE, 6-9
-- President Clinton takes to the podium after being presented by
Attorney General Janet Reno on Wednesday at the Civil Rights Law
Enforcement Roundtable. Taking action against racial profiling,
President Clinton is ordering federal law enforcement officials to
collect data on the race and gender of the people they stop to
question or arrest. (Paul Hosefros/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT24) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- RICHARDSON-SPY-CASE, 6-9
-- Energy Secretary Bill Richardson looks at his charts during a
hearing before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on
Capitol Hill, Wednesday. The committee alleged spying by China at
U.S. nuclear laboratories. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT23) KUMANOVO, Macedonia -- June 9, 1999 -- KOSOVO-RDP-2, 6-9
-- British Lt. Gen. Michael Jackson, left, addresses reporters as
the head of the Yugoslav military delegation, Gen. Svetozar
Marjanovic, second from left, listens late Wednesday after they
signed a military agreement on the withdrawal of Yugoslav troops
from Kosovo. The announcement was made at the NATO military base in
Kumanovo, near the Kosovo border. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT22) NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. -- June 9, 1999 -- SMART-MICROWAVE,
6-9 -- Kit Keith Yam, a food-science professor at Rutgers
University, with a prototype of his intelligent microwave oven. Yam
and a team of researchers at Rutgers have succeeded in building a
microwave oven that can read the bar code on a bag of popcorn and
glean the popcorn's proper cooking time by referring to a data base
of information collected by food scientists. Eventually they hope
to develop a microwave oven that can sense what it is cooking.
(Norman Y. Lono/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT21) PHOENIX -- June 9, 1999 -- DRUG-TREATMENT, 6-9 -- Albert
Delatorre and Richard Rehard, both recovering drug addicts, before
their group therapy session. In defiance of Arizona's political
establishment, voters took the law into their own hands and voted
twice, by large majorities, to make their state the first to
mandate treatment instead of prison for criminal offenders whose
primary legal problem is drug use. (Monica Almeida/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT20) BAGHDAD, Iraq -- June 9, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JUNE 13
-- IRAQ-SANCTIONS-2-COX, 06-09 -- Hamed Khalaf, a 32-year-old
unemployed taxi driver, tries to sell his brothers' collection of
Arabic culture picture journals for about 40 cents at Baghdad's
outdoor book market. ``These are the last of what I have,'' he
explains. ``Next, I'll sell my clothes. I mean it.'' (Larry
Kaplow/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT19) BAGHDAD, Iraq -- June 9, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JUNE 13
-- IRAQ-SANCTIONS-COX, 06-09 -- People look for bargains at
Baghdad's outdoor book market, where many Iraqi's desperate for
money go to sell off family books and journals. ``These are the
last of what I have,'' explains Hamed Khalaf who sold off his
brothers' collection of Arabic culture picture journals for about
40 cents. ``Next, I'll sell my clothes. I mean it.'' (Larry
Kaplow/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT18) BAGHDAD, Iraq -- June 9, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JUNE 13
-- IRAQ-SCHOOL-2-COX, 06-09 -- A lone girl walks across the
courtyard of the Hidayeh (Enlightenment) Elementary School in
Baghdad. The school, with about 1,200 girls, has one telephone and
no copying machine. Lights are often out in the school, and many
students sit on the floors for lack of even a broken-down desk.
(Larry Kaplow/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT17) BAGHDAD, Iraq -- June 9, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JUNE 13
-- IRAQ-SCHOOL-1-COX, 06-09 -- Students fill the classroom at
Hidayeh (Enlightenment) Elementary School, a school in a
lower-middle class area of central Baghdad. In addition to lights
that are often out, many classes have more than 55 children forcing
students sit on the floor for lack of a desk. (Larry Kaplow/Cox
News Service Photo)

   (NYT16) UNDATED -- June 9, 1999 -- HOME-IMPROVEMENT, 6-9 --
After prolonged exposure to the elements, the color of wood in
outdoor structures, like decks, lawn furniture and gazeebos, turns
from a warm brown to a dingy gray. A number of products called deck
cleaners or revivers can be used to restore the natural color of
wood. (Edward R. Lipinski/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT15) ABOARD THE USS THEODORE ROOSEVELT -- June 9, 1999 --
KOSOVO-RDP, 6-9 -- A waist catapult safety observer gives a
thumbs-up to the pilot of an F/A-18 ``Hornet'' just before being
catapulted from the flight deck of the U.S. Navy aircraft carrier
on Wednesday. The Theodore Roosevelt and its carrier airwing, in
the Adriatic, are participating in air strikes against the
Yugoslavia (PhotographerUs Mate 3rd Class Donne McKissic/New York
Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT14) MIRKOVICI, Macedonia -- June 9, 1999 --
KOSOVO-SPYPLANE-COX, 06-09 -- Valentin Jovanovinski, Macedonian
civil aviation flight inspector, shows the radio-controlled drone
airplane confiscated by Macedonian police. ``Maybe it was for
commercial purposes, maybe it was for military purposes. I don't
know,'' he said. (Marcia Kunstel/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT13) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- EAMES-EXHIBITION-2, 06-09
-- A visitor to the ``The Work of Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy
of Invention'' exhibits admires the couple's laid back lounger with
ottoman. This chair is just one of the items on display as part of
the Library of Congress exhibit highlighting home furnishings
designed by the Eameses. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) WASHINGTON -- June 9, 1999 -- EAMES-EXHIBITION-1, 06-09
-- Vicki Walker, of Orange County, Va, sits in a chair (La Chaise)
at the exhibition, ``The Work of Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of
Invention.'' The notions that innovatively designed and
economically accessible objects like home furnishings designed by
the Eameses' could be ambassadors of cultural change, are still
radical. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT11) NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico -- June 9, 1999 --
CHRISTIAN-DOCTORS-HNS, 6-9 -- Alice Truong, a fourth year medical
student at the University of Texas, examines Margarita Ramirez, 49,
last month. A rocking chair, kept on blocks keep it from rocking,
was converted to a dentist's chair. The Christian Medical and
Dental Society, from San Antonio area, sponsors eight trips a year
to Mexican cities along the border northern Mexico border cities.
(Delcia Lopez/San Antonio Express-News)

   (NYT10) MENLO PARK, Calif. -- June 9, 1999 --
ANTHROPOLOGISTS-TECHNOLOGY, 6-9 -- Bonnie Nardi in her office at
AT&T Labs West. Ms. Nardi left academia in 1984 and is considered a
pioneer among anthropologists who are employed by high-tech
companies to examine consumers' behavior in their homes and
offices. (Dan Krauss/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) FORT DIX, N.J. -- June 9, 1999 -- REFUGEES-INTERNET, 6-9
-- Bedri Dragusha, a Kosovar Albanian refugee being housed in the
military facility, looks for information on a Web site in the
Internet trailer at the base. The U.S. Information Agency has set
up the Kosovar Refugee Internet Assistance Initiative to assist
refugees in finding friends and relatives. (Jeff Zelevansky/New
York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- STEINWAY-TECHNOLOGY-2, 6-9 --
Michael Selak strings a piano at Steinway & Sons with the use of a
device that helps perform the task more efficiently. Steinway &
Sons employees are using advanced technology for some of the steps
in building pianos. (Craig Wallace Dale/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- STEINWAY-TECHNOLOGY-1, 6-9 --
James Argenziano, a mechanical engineer at Steinway & Sons, using a
device to measure a piano's iron plate. Without the device, this
type of measurement would take hours. Steinway & Sons employees are
using advanced technology for some of the steps in building pianos.
(Craig Wallace Dale/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT6) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- SHAG-RESURGENCE-2, 6-9 --
Alan Sanchez, 39, sits on his newly pruchased shag carpet as his
daughter Anne Sarah, 3, plays in the livingroom of their Brooklyn
home on Saturday. Sanchez, who purchased the shag for about $100,
grew up in a heavily shagged home which left a bad taste on his
esthetic palate. ``But in retrospect,'' he says, ``I kind of like
the idea'' of owning one. Now he wants another one. (Jeffery A.
Salter/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT5) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- SHAG-RESURGENCE-1, 6-9 --
Dali Singh, of ABC Carpets and Home, shows shag carpet called Greek
Flokati. Until recently, this furriest of floor coverings had been
written off as the ultimate home-furnishing faux pas. Now, with the
help of movies like ``Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me,''
carpet stores can hardly keep them in stock. (Keith Meyers/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT4) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- WEGMAN-AT-HOME-4, 6-9 --
Photographer William Wegman with Battina, 9, one of his
Weimaraners, in his apartment in Chelsea. Wegman, the conceptual
artist and dog-theme merchandizer, lives in a 5,300-square-foot
apartment which was previously a nursery school. (Fred R.
Conrad/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT3) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- WEGMAN-AT-HOME-3, 6-9 --
William Wegman and his wife Christine Burgin, holding daughter
18-month old daughter Lola, watch their son Atlas, 4, hanging
around on their rooftop garden. Wegman, the conceptual artist and
dog-theme merchandizer, and his family live in a 5,300-square-foot
apartment which was previously a nursery school. (Fred R.
Conrad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT2) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- WEGMAN-AT-HOME-2, 6-9 --
Hardy materials set the tone in the Wegman loft like the concrete
and plywood kitchen. Wegman is the conceptual artist and dog-theme
merchandizer whose fans have responded to his work as if answering
the siren call of a high-pitched dog whistle. (Fred R. Conrad/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) NEW YORK -- June 9, 1999 -- WEGMAN-AT-HOME-1, 6-9 --
Photographer William Wegman sweet-talks one of his Weimaraners,
Battina, 9, as her son, Chippy, 4, looks on during a photo shoot in
his apartment. Wegman works primarily with four Weimaraners, but
only Battina and Chippy live in his 5,300-square-foot apartment
which was previously a nursery school. (Fred R. Conrad/New York
Times Photo) LITE

   The New York Times News Service

(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.
